content:
You have functors F:C→D,G:D→CF:{\sf C \to D}, G:{\sf D\to C}F:C→D,G:D→C, and G∘FG\circ FG∘F fixes an object B∈C0B\in{\sf C}_0B∈C0​. You also have a path (A→aB→bA)∈C2(A\overset{a}{\to}B\overset{b}{\to}A) \in {\sf C}_2(A→aB→bA)∈C2​. What would you call a “mixed” path like the following?

b∘CG(…∘D…)F∘Ca:A⇝Ab\circ_{\sf C}G(\ldots\circ_{\sf D}\ldots)F\circ_{\sf C}a:A\leadsto Ab∘C​G(…∘D​…)F∘C​a:A⇝A

That is, a composite through multiple categories whose diagram may not commute, that is may not correspond to any endomorphism of AAA in C1\sf C_1C1​.

it is awkward, but this captures an important computation, and if I am to build a category whose paths are such morphisms, it would be convenient to have a term for them while doing so.

In case that's not helpful, here's a simpler question; if I call the center part "the image of BBB under G(…∘D…)FG(\ldots\circ_{\sf D}\ldots)FG(…∘D​…)F" and assign that image a name, what notation would easily communicate to you "this is not necessarily a morphism in C\sf CC"?

I don't understand what the center part even means, I don't think? I can understand G(…∘D…),G(\ldots\circ_D\ldots),G(…∘D​…), it's GGG of some morphism in D,\mathsf D,D, but I don't understand how to parse F∘CaF\circ_C aF∘C​a or G(…∘D…)FG(\ldots\circ_D\ldots)FG(…∘D​…)F separately, and it doesn't look any clearer what they mean together.

Hmmmm... does this help? Everything on the bottom is in C\sf CC, we leave C\sf CC and then we return to the same object we left, but in a way that may not correspond to any morphism within C\sf CC.

I'm thinking of G…FG\ldots FG…F as "the action of -thing- on BBB", I don't know if others will understand that, though.

@Eric M Downes Just for confirmation, do you mean that your path A⇝AA \leadsto AA⇝A of the form:

A→aB→G(f0)G(X1)→G(f1)…G(Xn)→G(fn)B→bAA \mathop{\to}\limits^{a} B \mathop{\to}\limits^{G(f_0)} G(X_1) \mathop{\to}\limits^{G(f_1)} \dots G(X_{n}) \mathop{\to}\limits^{G(f_n)} B \mathop{\to}\limits^{b} AA→aB→G(f0​)G(X1​)→G(f1​)…G(Xn​)→G(fn​)B→bA

such that f0f_0f0​ is an arrow of the form F(B)→X1F(B) \to X_1F(B)→X1​ in D\mathsf{D}D and fnf_nfn​ is an arrow of the form Xn→F(B)X_{n} \to F(B)Xn​→F(B) in D\mathsf{D}D?

If I had to formalize these paths, I would probably start looking at the category of AAA-elements over the functor GGG (let us denote it as A↓GA\downarrow GA↓G) whose

  • objects are pairs (x:A→G(X),X∈Obj(C))(x:A \to G(X),X \in \mathsf{Obj}(\mathsf{C}))(x:A→G(X),X∈Obj(C))
  • and whose arrows (x:A→G(X),X)→(y:A→G(Y),Y)(x:A \to G(X),X) \to (y:A \to G(Y),Y) (x:A→G(X),X)→(y:A→G(Y),Y) are given by arrows f:X→Yf:X \to Yf:X→Y in D\mathsf{D}D such that G(f)∘x=yG(f) \circ x = yG(f)∘x=y

In fact, I would consider the category A↓G↓AA\downarrow G \downarrow AA↓G↓A whose

  • objects are triple (x:A→G(X),x′:G(X)→A,X∈Obj(C))(x:A \to G(X), x':G(X) \to A,X \in \mathsf{Obj}(\mathsf{C}))(x:A→G(X),x′:G(X)→A,X∈Obj(C))
  • and whose arrows (x:A→G(X),x′:G(X)→A,X)→(y:A→G(Y),y′:G(Y)→A,Y)(x:A \to G(X), x':G(X) \to A,X) \to (y:A \to G(Y), y':G(Y) \to A,Y) (x:A→G(X),x′:G(X)→A,X)→(y:A→G(Y),y′:G(Y)→A,Y) are given by arrows f:X→Yf:X \to Yf:X→Y in D\mathsf{D}D such that G(f)∘x=yG(f) \circ x = yG(f)∘x=y and y′∘G(f)=x′y' \circ G(f)= x'y′∘G(f)=x′
Then, your path is an endo-path on the object (a,b,F(B))(a,b,F(B))(a,b,F(B)) in the category A↓G↓AA \downarrow G \downarrow AA↓G↓A

@Eric M Downes Actually, I went a bit too fast! With the information that you provided, your path is in fact a path of the form:

(a,b′,F(B))→⋯→(a′,b,F(B))(a,b',F(B)) \to \dots \to (a',b,F(B))(a,b′,F(B))→⋯→(a′,b,F(B))

in A↓G↓AA \downarrow G \downarrow AA↓G↓A. It is only an endopath if G(fn)∘⋯∘G(f0)=idBG(f_n) \circ \dots \circ G(f_0) = \mathsf{id}_BG(fn​)∘⋯∘G(f0​)=idB​.
In the simplest possible case I can construct γ:=G(fn)∘…∘G(f0)\gamma:=G(f_n)\circ\ldots\circ G(f_0)γ:=G(fn​)∘…∘G(f0​) satisfies γ∘γ=idB\gamma\circ\gamma=id_{B}γ∘γ=idB​.

Another way to get such heteromorphisms is through profunctors, which make precise the idea that these paths don't compose with themselves but can be precomposed and postcomposed by arbitrary morphisms. This one should be the composite of Hom(-, F) and Hom(G, -).
(Kinda -- you seem to fix some objects & look at the 'endoheteromorphisms' but that's extra manipulations on top of the profunctor, ie fix A and A as arguments)
